author: {'steamid': '76561198023555368', 'num_games_owned': 3343, 'num_reviews': 171, 'playtime_forever': 1490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1490, 'last_played': 1552840991}
review:
[b]Mages of Mystralia[/b] is a worthwhile indie adventure/rpg with a fun and unique make-your-own spellcrafting mechanic (including optional puzzles you can solve with hand-crafted spells). The occasional, required, solve the chain puzzles were a another welcome addition in my book.

The hardest difficulty isn‚Äôt well thought out. I could manage the enemies but even the first boss is just a huge HP soaker that deals nearly one-hit kills. That‚Äôs when I discovered they don‚Äôt let you change difficulty without starting over--two or three hours needlessly wasted. There is no warning about this when you start the game.

Mages felt slow at first but after the second boss the game picks up and the fun kicked in for me. The world feels empty at times, I think reducing the overall map size would‚Äôve helped. As is, it feels as if they wanted to artificially stretch out the length of the game from ~7hrs to ~15hrs.

In game music sounded great, I see now on the store page it was performed by Video Game Orchestra which also did Final Fantasy XV and Kingdom Hearts. The sound effects get the job done but the small number of sounds are repeated frequently.

Seems like there are 4 or 5 enemies and the rest are re-skins. I liked the large mini-bosses because you could get them to charge off the cliff.

The story felt predictable and the script was definitely translated from a different language. I liked the optional, sometimes humorous, quests you could initiate with many of the villagers if you listened to their stories.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022184741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1061, 'last_played': 1551059611}
review:
This game has a lot of the same hooks as a Zelda game: an adventure game where you build your tool kit over time to get better at combat and realize more options for solving puzzles. It has a similar aesthetic. The spell crafting is fun to experiment with and refine; and is what separates this game from a Zelda clone. 

It's a compact game. I got 100% completion in about 13 total hours played. To me this is a positive. I'd rather have a compact game with focused gameplay + unique challenges than something which is unnecessarily repetitive to offer "more game."

review: It's like Legend of Zelda + Magicka. The main problem is pretty low difficulty. Most puzzles are solved by creating one spell specifically for this situation. Dungeons are linear. But game is pretty short (less than 14h for 100% achievments) and ends faster than you get bored.

review:
This is one of those game I put on wishlist and wonder if I would enjoy it or not and it end up being fun (glad the sales entice me to give it a go). 

I enjoyed the puzzle solving. Certain puzzle need certain spell combination, so if you're missing 1 or a few, you'll need to look for it and back-track to solve it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998508603', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 724, 'last_played': 1548122337}
review: A fun little ARPG romp. The big draw here is the customizability of your spells - the rune system is really interesting, and every time you unlock a new effect there's a moment of "okay, what kind of neat stuff can I make my spells do now?" I kinda wish you were able to unlock the elements more quickly at the start so you could get building even quicker, but I get that it's basically the core progression, so... /shrug.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993208673', 'num_games_owned': 1794, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 992, 'last_played': 1547283569}
review:
The Good:
+ Lovely overall art style and environments
+ Interesting magic system, quite unlike anything I've seen before.
+ Native support for PS4 controllers w/correct button icons.
+ Multiple save slots (quite uncommon these days)
+ Map lets you know what areas have secrets remaining.
    
The Bad:
- Ends with a 'To Be Continued' style cutscene.
- Story is more like an outline then something properly fleshed out.
- World lighting not updated to reflect most significant story event.
- Character animation in cutscenes is generally quite bad.
- Magic system is more confusing & limited then it should have been.
- Some minor technical issues with shadows through out the game.
    
Final thoughts; It's a good, but incomplete game. Basically it feels like they got 3/4 through development and then stopped and polished what they had. That said, what is there is fun and entertaining enough that I 100% the game, so yes I think its a game I can recommend.

Side note: If you like 'World to the West' then you'll also like this game, and vise versa, as they're similar to the point where they feel like alternate reality versions of each other.

([url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/39309883-Indie-Bullet-Point-Reviews/]Indie Bullet Point Reviews[/url])

author: {'steamid': '76561198014698888', 'num_games_owned': 924, 'num_reviews': 240, 'playtime_forever': 906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 906, 'last_played': 1574829248}
review:
[b]TLDR: Play this game. It is fantastic! Unique customizable spell crafting, great story, great soundtrack, great art, epic boss fights, challenging (and optional) environmental puzzles.  There is nothing not to love.[/b]


You play as Zia, a young and impressionable girl who just discovered she is a mage by burning down her home.  Now you need to learn to master that newfound spellcrafting ability to save the world from some mysterious powers emerging amid a solar eclipse.  I don't want to spoil the story for you, but let me just briefly say it is quite good!  The game masterfully introduces Mystralia lore to you as you play so that you slowly begin to understand the history of the land and why Mages are feared.

Mages of Mystralia brings a completely unique mechanic to the magic-casting RPG adventure genre.  You don't level up, there is no gear or inventory to manage, there is no skill tree, you don't have to pick one power at the cost of never being able to pick a different one.  Instead, you get the ability to fully customize your spells with a wide variety of Runes, and the only concern you have is how quickly you use your Mana.  My personal favorite spell that I created caused lightning balls to fall on enemies, freeze enemies on impact, detonate with a shockwave on the ground, and repeatedly cast itself while enemies were in proximity, but it went through my fully-upgraded Mana stores in about 2 seconds.  Four spell types, four elements, and eighteen runes can be placed on the spellcrafting grid in order to create tons of incredible combinations!

As you play through the game, you'll find a number of staves that can enhance your favorite elements or grant you various other benefits.  You'll also collect purple Soulbeads to offer at a shrine in the Mage hideout that can increase your Health and Mana.  Many of these are hidden in unique enemy encounters or one of the many environmental puzzles that cover the landscape.  These puzzles are optional, but they are fun and challenging to solve.  I think one of the best thing about them is they actually encourage you to experiment with your Runes to discover new combinations that you may not have put together on your own.

While your spell crafting genius may keep you alive from the hordes of goblins roaming the Mystralia valley, the place where the mechanic shines is in the boss fights.  The bosses are designed to get you to use those Runes you collect as you play through the game.  Prepare for some fast-based, epic fights.  Flame, rocks, lightning, and ice will be flying through the air while you dodge skeletons, boars, bombs, goblins, and more in order to take out the bosses and restore order to Mystralia.

As you may expect, the slow gaining of Runes allows you to cast ever changing spells that in turn grants access to more and more of the map.  Mystralia is a somewhat open world for you to explore, and you will find numerous reasons to backtrack and collect those chests you couldn't quite reach when you first wandered through an area.  However, even with the Metroidvania style of exploration, the game never feels like you are needlessly backtracking.  The world is just the right size to explore, and the reward for finding all of its secrets is hours of fun!

Play this game.  You won't regret it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198018144553', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 799, 'last_played': 1546834829}
review:
Disclaimer: [olist] [*]When I review games, I tend to focus on the negative aspects that I find lacking, annoying, or otherwise detrimental to the game itself. The reason behind this is simple; the good things in a game speak for themselves. If I don‚Äôt write about something (like sound, controls, graphics), it is because I found that component of the game to be at the very least adequate. In the rare occasion that I find some component of a game to be superlative, I will give praise. But as that word suggests, it is quite rare. [*]When I play games, I play for enjoyment. I play for the story. I play for immersion. To me, it becomes rather irksome when a challenge in a video game presents itself as a requirement. Challenges in video games should be like Emerald/Ruby Weapon in Final Fantasy VII; completely optional, non-story/progress impacting, and up to the player as to whether or not they want to go for it. I do not find them fun in any way, shape, or form. [*]If I find myself stuck at a particular moment in a game for too long or with too much difficulty, I will rate the game negatively. I don‚Äôt like my time being wasted and if I cannot progress in the game, I will shelf it permanently in favor of something that is actually fun to me. I don‚Äôt want challenges when I game. I don‚Äôt want to be frustrated by a game. I don‚Äôt want to do the same crap over and over. All of these things defeat the idea of ‚Äúentertainment‚Äù to me. There are entire genres of games that I avoid for this reason. Dark Souls, Cuphead, and their ilk aren‚Äôt fun to me. I‚Äôm not driven by that kind of time wasting. [*]If you‚Äôre one of those Cheeto-eating basement-dwellers right now that is reading this while muttering ‚Äúgit gud‚Äù or some other variant thereof, I have a handy-dandy list of bodily orifices for you to consult. Once you‚Äôre comfortable with the failure that is yourself, you should choose one of these orifices and promptly place your head in it. [/olist] Onward.

[b]All of the problems with Mages Of Mystralia:[/b] [list] [*][b]Label the puzzles. [/b]If I can‚Äôt figure out how to complete a puzzle in a game, I go to the internet. If puzzles aren‚Äôt tagged with some sort of identifier, it means that I have to search through some weeb‚Äôs YouTube playthrough and find the moment they do the puzzle. This is [b]a hideous waste of time[/b]. The only puzzles in this game that have titles in them are the door puzzles (which are easily the most yawn-inducing part of this game). If you need to search for help on a puzzle, good luck using the right words. ‚ÄúBut HelioFugal, the puzzles are the game.‚Äù NO. The STORY is the game. The gameplay is the game. LITERALLY EVERYTHING OTHER THAN THE PUZZLES IS BETTER IN THIS GAME. If I wanted to dance around staring at the same mundane crap for hours, I‚Äôd buy a Hanayama, shove it down the developer‚Äôs throat, and watch them groan in pain when they poop it out 8 hours later. [/list] [list] [*][b]Hints in the puzzles are completely useless. [/b]Within the game, you can purchase hints for every puzzle with these green orbs. All they do is tell you what runes you need to use. They don‚Äôt hint about how or what spell to place them in. If you don‚Äôt see that one extra thing that the developers thought was witty, you‚Äôll sit around trying to figure out the ‚Äúsolution‚Äù for hours (or in my case, about 5 minutes before going to youtube and fighting with the LACK OF LABELS). There are many other puzzles as well where the hint will tell you ‚Äúyou need xyz bull‚Äù and the easiest solution actually ends up needing you to procure a horse, 16 chickens, and that one rune that IT DIDN‚ÄôT SAY YOU NEEDED. The puzzles and their "hints" are just[b] badly designed[/b]. [/list] [list] [*][b]Dear Sweet Jesus, can you rip off Diablo more? [/b]The goblin designs in this game look and act and even attack in similar fashion to EVERY. DIABLO. GAME. EVER. This is what people with brains call ‚Äú[b]Plagiarism[/b].‚Äù Speaking of brains‚Ä¶. [/list] [list] [*][b]Almighty Mages that can‚Äôt swim? [/b]Complete bull. Your idiot-savant-turned-mage character can conjure up the most complicated spells with relative ease yet she can‚Äôt swim? Did the developers get dropped on their heads a lot as children or did the house just collapse on their encephalopathic excuses for a brain? I can understand this for the lava levels but with literally anywhere else, [b]this makes no sense[/b]. [/list] [list] [*][b]What‚Äôs worse? Autosaving or eating Donald Trump‚Äôs feces? [/b]That‚Äôs a rhetorical question given the fact that half of the US is sitting at the dinner table blindfolded with spoons out. But I digress. When will these dumb-as-bricks developers get it through their third-deviation-to-the-left skulls that [b]autosaving is a STUPID IDEA[/b]. Every time I find a game with autosaving, I immediately cringe. What if I want to mess with my save files? What if I want to roll back to a point in the game so that I can experiment with some component at some point? What If I encounter a game-crippling bug? I now have to start over? Screw. That. When you‚Äôre playing a single player game, there is no excuse for autosaving. It‚Äôs a scourge on gaming that is equivalent to videogaming Ebola. [/list] [list] [*][b]What the crap is with all the ladders that you CAN‚ÄôT CLIMB?[/b] All throughout the game, the developers put ladders EVERYWHERE in logical places that might imply ‚ÄúOh, I should climb that.‚Äù Nope. You can‚Äôt. And the weird thing is that I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs worse: [b]A playable character that is too stupid to swim AND climb ladders[/b] or a developer that thought ‚Äúyes, this makes sense to me.‚Äù [/list] [list] [*][b]Consistent grammar and spelling mistakes irk the crap out of me. [/b]It‚Äôs not spelled ‚Äúartefact‚Äù and it‚Äôs not spelled ‚Äúcristal.‚Äù These kinds of things are like when I reviewed Vampyr which for a French game decided that gimmick would only work well in English. These kind of ‚Äúintentional‚Äù spelling errors are neither witty nor cute. They make me think [b]the developers are dumber than wet socks.[/b] [/list] [list] [*][b]The Puzzles seem to have been designed by a 16-year-old slightly-pubescent boy that still isn‚Äôt quite sure where a clitoris is and what it actually does. [/b]What I mean by this is that [b]you will spend a lot of time trying a lot of things that don‚Äôt work[/b] and after a while she‚Äôll lose patience, get you to Jackson Pollock as quickly as possible, and then go bed completely unsatisfied. Seriously, a lot of the puzzles in this game are so badly designed that Jeffrey Dahmer would have apologized to the world on the developer's behalf. I spent about 10 minutes trying to figure out the chandelier puzzle in whatever-leaf Hamlet before realizing that I could just spam fireballs with bounce enabled until it accidentally hit the torch that completed the puzzle. I later looked up the solution which was so far from what I did it‚Äôs laughable and no hint could have brought me to the ‚Äúsolution‚Äù these coked-up invalids brought to the table. The openness of the spell system creates so much disarray that if you aren‚Äôt thinking about that ONE tiny thing that developer had in mind (more often than not) you won‚Äôt get the solution and are better off just trying everything like the aforementioned 16-year-old. The only difference here is that the puzzle won‚Äôt fake a climax when you mash all the wrong buttons. [/list] In summary, I'd recommend Polio before this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970861139', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1897, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1136, 'last_played': 1618468723}
review:
One of my favorite games of all time, but not perfect.

Spell crafting becomes incredibly deep and interesting towards the end as the number of available runes and elemental masteries grows, and with 10 wands to choose from, there's incredible strategic potential.  However, you have to be willing to experiment to learn what all your options are, and if you don't pay attention to the brief tutorials the game offers when new categoies of runes are introduced, the behavior may seem confusing because you wouldn't know which connections to pay attention to... so read those tutorials carefully.

With the control schemes, you can either go with keyboard and mouse for precise location aim but 8-directional movement, or a gamepad with precise movement but radial direction aiming.  This is particularly significant because your spells have limited auto-aiming properties that are earier to specify if you can click on the exact thing you want your spells to target, rather than in the general direction of several possible targets.  I recommend trying both options to find what works best for you.

The music is excellent, the story is fine, the art style is endearing, but the graphical detail is below par for a 21st century computer game.  This didn't detract from the fun, but it did catch my attention during a few of the cutscenes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067098756', 'num_games_owned': 1550, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1561475962}
review:
It's a solid "meh" as far as I'm concerned.
Playing with a controller as recommended by the game.
Overall it's very cute + had some (at face value) interesting concepts, but the implementation of it just doesn't feel up to par.

The magic customization is cool, but not particularly intuitive on how each modifier will interact with each spell.
Linking <movement> -> Fire -> <right> will have a different effect than say <right> -> <movement> -> Fire.
One fires a round arc, the other fires a firebolt to your immediate right.
The <right> modifies different things, so it interacts differently. Okay, I get that.
But then you toss in other modifiers like Overcharge, Mastery, and whatever and they either don't care what they're linked with, or don't function in a way that you've just established they would function?
Overcharge says if you hold the spell you get more damage. Well, no, you don't. It does the same damage regardless. But it changes the basic form (and makes it worse, frankly).
The basic lightning attack is a quick swipe in an arc in front of you.
It's quick, low-mana, and lets you hit-stun enemies.
Overcharge roots you in place, shifts the contact point forwards, delays contact, and delays animation.
This leads to you doing less damage, taking more damage, and getting perma stunned far more frequently. But hey the graphic is bigger.

There's tons of slots so I expect tons of interactions but it feels very much trial & error at this point.
I wouldn't mind this T&E so much if the combat itself wasn't so iffy.
It feels more like you're fighting against the limitations of the mechanics than you are experimenting or making something cool with your spells. 
Another review criticized the linear feel of the maps, which I'd read prior to buying but decided to try it anyways. 
The maps are quite twisty at times, and fun to explore but the explorable area (gated often by content blocks you've yet to unlock) are basically thin corridors which limit the use of directional & custom spells as they'll often just fizzle upon contact with fence, cliff, or other boundary.

There's hitstun + animation lock for both you & the enemies.
There's no recovery period after being hitstunned.
This leads to you often getting perma stunned or stuck in hit recovery loops, which leads to a lot of 
>fire 1 spell, then backpedal
basic kiting, which is hardly a fun implementation of all this spell customization.
I'm stuck at the Ice Lizard boss right now, purely because there's no telegraph for 2 of its hardest hitting attacks, which seem to randomly target the board in wide range aoe. 
Pure RNG whether or not you'll live thru boss mechanics annoys me to no end.
Made worse by the annoying hitstun implementation, as you're often taking dmg from follow-up attacks as you're stuck in hit recovery animation. Nvm the infinite-spawning adds that will group up and poke you to death if you get caught by anything. Basically more layered rng whether you'll survive taking a 5% dmg hit or if you'll go 100-0 because hurr durr you're chain stunned now, get fk'd.

To further compound this, there's a delay on dodge/block... so you often take dmg despite anticipating the attacks just because your shield didn't activate in time, or you dodge and you don't actually move or take dmg while moving. 

Music's okay. Mini puzzles are okay, if a bit obvious on what the expected solution is.
The first Tree boss was well done.

Not sure what the currency's for yet, you seem to be flooded with the green ones, so the only thing I've been able to buy cost ~90 and i have 800. Teleports cost 10? 16? something like that. Purple orbs seem to translate into (max?) hp/mp upgrades.
I'm only 3 hours in at this point, so take that with a grain of salt.. but this early it just feels kinda blah when you find a chest and it has oh boy 30 green little nuggets in it cuz it's not like you can't get that many from just breaking some barrels, and there's nothing to buy with them yet anyways.

The music's okay, the story/scenario's okay so far, and the graphics are cute enough. Like it's visually pleasing & would otherwise be enjoyable, just the actual combat and meat of the game makes it feel hollow.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018969559', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 638, 'last_played': 1546143455}
review: Cute top down adventure game. The spellcraft mechanics are pretty awesome and there are some clever bits, though honestly with the exception of specific puzzles I didn't use very many variations of spells as once you find the optimal combat spells you just stick with them. It's a medium length game (10 hrs to 100% and get all achievements---it doesn't have any unreasonable "find all 500 eggs" achievements, I got 26/30 of them in one playthrough) so it didn't outstay its welcome which is often what a game like this does.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052792745', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1208, 'last_played': 1545754415}
review:
I am happy that I found this game in a random explore queue and bought it ( BEFORE SALE so full price ) because I enjoyed every second of playing it. And I didn't regret paying the full price at all. 

You start out in this game as the Mage Girl Zia who is on her quest to become a full fledged mage to be able to restore what has been broken and to help out people. Nothing further in terms of story will be spoilered in this review. 

The world itself is really cute and I love the drawn style of it. It doesnt look animated in the slightest but like.. a weird drawn picture and I appreciate that haha. 

Graphic wise and art wise its a really cute and cool game, definitely children based tho. Like even tho adults would appreciate this art aswell it is usually something you see in games for a younger audience. Really awesome I liked it. 

The music was also pretty cool. I wouldn't say anything astonishing or out of this world but pretty solid and it made up for a chill relaxing atmosphere playing this game. In terms of sounds I also enjoyed that the people in this game have their own language in terms of sounds and it was super cute and enjoyable. 

Gameplay is the strong aspect of this game tho. You have so many different options it is amazing. Playing as a mage who gathers runes to create spells YOURSELF through combining different runes together, the sheer numbers of options are amazing. You can combine so many different aspects of spells and behaviours that it always ends up as a "wow" moment when you use the spell you created for the first time. Alot of puzzles, different enemies and general side missions also require a vast variety of different spells you gotta combine exactly for specific challenges and I gotta be honest, that was not always easy. I broke my head over some of the puzzles and I enjoyed every second of it. I played this game to 100% on the hardest difficulty and it gave me a great and fun little challenge that I enjoyed for the time it lasted. 

Really great game, definitely recommending it! 

~ ShikiX

review:
„Ç¢„ÇØ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„Ç¢„Éâ„Éô„É≥„ÉÅ„É£„Éº„Éë„Ç∫„É´„ÄÅÈõ£ÊòìÂ∫¶„ÅØÊôÆÈÄö„ÅÆ„É¢„Éº„Éâ„ÅßÔºëÔºêÔºêÔºÖ„ÇØ„É™„Ç¢„ÅßÁ¥ÑÔºëÔºïÊôÇÈñì„ÄÅ„Ç¢„ÇØ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥Ë¶ÅÁ¥†„Éë„Ç∫„É´Ë¶ÅÁ¥†„ÅØ‰∏ÄÈÉ®„ÇíÈô§„ÅçÂü∫Êú¨ÁöÑ„Å´ÂÑ™„Åó„ÇÅ„ÄÅ„Åü„Å†Êïµ„ÅåÂ§ö„ÅÑ„ÄÅÁä∂ÊÖãÁï∞Â∏∏„ÅÆÊîªÊíÉ„ÅåËøΩÂ∞æ„Åó„Å¶„Åè„Çã„Å™„Å©„ÅßÂõ≤„Åæ„Çå„Çã„Å®ÈÄüÊîª„ÅßÊ≠ª„Çì„Å†„Çä„ÇÇ„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÅÂ∫èÁõ§„ÅØÈ≠îÊ≥ï„ÇÇÂ∞ë„Å™„Åè„Åß„Åç„Çã„Åì„Å®„ÅåÂ∞ë„Å™„ÅÑ„Åå‰∏≠Áõ§Ëæ∫„Çä„Åã„ÇâÊèÉ„Å£„Å¶„Åç„Å¶„Åã„Çâ„ÅåÊú¨Áï™„ÄÅÁµÑ„ÅøÂêà„Çè„Åõ„ÅßËâ≤„ÄÖ„Å®Âá∫Êù•„Çã„ÄÅÂú∞Âõ≥„Å´„Ç¢„Ç§„ÉÜ„É†„ÇÑÈ≠îÊ≥ï„Åå‰ΩïÂÄã„ÅÇ„Çã„Åã„Å®„ÅãÊõ∏„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÅÇ„Çã„ÅÆ„ÅßÂæåÂçäÈ≠îÊ≥ïÊèÉ„Å£„Å¶„Åã„ÇâÂèñ„Çä„Å´Ë°å„Å£„Åü„Çä„ÇÇÂÆπÊòì„Å†

What a pleasure this game is to play. It‚Äôs got an engaging story,  beautiful art, a lovely soundtrack and great spell ‚Äúbuilding‚Äù mechanics. I finished the main story but have only completed 60% of the game. After finishing it puts you back in the beginning village so I‚Äôm looking forward to exploring some more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066422046', 'num_games_owned': 677, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 713, 'last_played': 1648855883}
review: It has spellcrafting, and does it excellently. More games should have spellcrafting. It looks great, has some fun puzzles, and the story (though not spectacular) does its job.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987615677', 'num_games_owned': 2097, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 857, 'last_played': 1538223471}
review:
First of all I must really stress it that this is a really good game.

It's not the lengthiest of them all, but it finished in the right moment. 

The mechanics are quite original, the overall vibe I felt is something in the lines of Legend of Zelda and Magicka games.
The whole game isn't only about combat and spellcasting, but there are also some puzzle mechanics (which use same rules as spellcrafting), and fun exploration elements.

Player power progression in the game doesn't stop until you unlock everything, I've got around 80% completion (and finished the story) at the time of writing this review - every "modifier" I've found so far was useful in a way to my spell combos. At this point I don't think there are more challenging encounters for me (playing on Archmage difficulty), but I wonder what other spells can I create.

Now to the meat... The core of the game is that you're a mage, creating your own spells from blocks and a root element, which you can change later on in the game. There are four base spells, you can create six spells of each kind, and chain them to create your own little armageddon spell. Overall the toolkit is very satisfying.

I don't want to write too much, but just as an example - there's a blast spell available, to which when you apply fire element and move command you get a... Moving fireblast. Then you can, for example, add a trigger to the spell so it's cast on hit, let's say... Homing triple frost blasts, which then spawn an explosion on hit. 
Every spell cast in the chain costs mana, so this is not giving the player too much power, but can create a very satisfying effects. The game is made in a way that enables player to create an arsenal of spells which is very useful and yet - not really too overpowered. (which is, to be honest, a very subjective matter in the case of single player action adventure game like this)

Honestly - I wish for a continuation or DLC for this game to happen, it was very satisfying to play through, I plan to find the rest of secrets/spell modifiers that are left there in the enchanting world of Mystralia.

author: {'steamid': '76561198247158532', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 1696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1696, 'last_played': 1533172169}
review:
Juego de rol, aventuras y puzzle. El personaje es una aprendiz de mago que debe ir aprendiendo y desarrollando su habilidad a lo largo del juego. La rama de hechizos y las combinaciones posibles de las mismas son incre√≠bles y √∫nicas; pocas veces te vas a sentir tan mago como en este juego.
La jugabilidad fluida, puzzle desafiantes, muy buena historia, gr√°ficos coloridos y la dificultad en ascenso lo convierten en una completa maravilla. Sin dudarlo es un 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011439513', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 27864, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17197, 'last_played': 1580065357}
review:
This game is incredibly fun. The spellcrafting aspect is simple yet complex in your possibilities and the bosses feature unique concepts. There is a lot to explore and alot of fun puzzles with different ways to beat them. However the controls are a bit finnicky if you do not own a controller, but if you want to enjoy the game with a mouse and keyboard, you can. 
All in all I definitely recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007439486', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 703, 'last_played': 1693468454}
review:
A fun, top down spell slinger wit a bit of magic creation. 

Early primary kids were able to watch and enjoy, despite a few scary moments. However, they would have struggled to play alone as a result of some of the mechanics. 

Best enjoyed  with a controller.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140101650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1084, 'last_played': 1623390258}
review: Hmm i had fun, playing with magic was fun. the ending though was quite disapointingly short. As in ending 2 stages(lava getto and dark tower) was way shorter than any of the other stages early on. the monsters were kinda repeating with changing colour. but overall recommend this fun game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198334547150', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2158, 'last_played': 1531685947}
review: Fantastic game, especially if you are looking for a casual game with an innovative magic system. The game is not particularly long but I really enjoyed playing around with the spell creation to figure out how the different interactions worked. In general, determining the best combinations for both combat and puzzle completions was interesting and enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065757028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1535277273}
review:
Do I like this game? Yes. Is it enjoyable despite it's flaws? Yes. Do i recommend it? No.
As to the good: The magic creation is wonderful.  Every time you get a new modifier for your spells you spend a few minutes just tinkering around and having a blast finding out the new stuff you can do.  And jesus, the moment you get triggers, the game changes into some crazy mage recursion that no game has ever implemented so ambitiously.  So building specific magic is wonky but fun, however there is very little to actually.... use the magic on.  Every single puzzle in this entire game has an only-one-method-solves-it solution.  Your progress and puzzle solving is gated by a plethora of obstacles that can only be interacted upon with exactly 1 type of magic each.  This normally isnt a large problem but those obstacles are the ONLY non-monster things in the entire game that your magic can interact with.  So the issue is that you have this incredibly diverse and open spell casting system in a world with utterly no openess.  You cant solve problems in clever ways or feel great about unique spell combos that overcome some unique difficulty, because the only difficulties are A) generic monsters you can just punch to death anyways, and B) Generic obstacles that are destroyed or bypassed by incredibly specific magic.

Honestly, as far as gameplay goes, the game would have been better if all the key obstacle-destroying magics were attainable from the start, so that you could at least figure out which specific spells interact with which barriers instead of being spoonfed the mind numbing iterative loop of progression they give you.

I swear this game is just a bunch of contrasts being shoved together: Open and diverse magic - Linear generic world.  Complex and thought provoking magic creation - Mind numbingly tedious implementation.

Anyhow, despite my complaints, the game is good enough that I'm sure a certain niche audience will love it, and all power to them!  It was a good attempt, and if Borealys Games publishes anything else I'll almost certainly check it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020781657', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 540, 'last_played': 1587955450}
review:
I've now beaten this game on the PS4 and PC andI totally forgot to write a review for this game - time to fix that right now!

First of all, this is THE wizard game in my library by FAR - I still have yet to play another game that actually makes me feel like a master of spells rather than a spammer of one or two.

The biggest drawback of this game is the pacing, but it needs to be stated and cleared up from the get-go to fully enjoy this game.  It starts in a weird marriage of Legend of Zelda and fairytale pacing and storylines.  The problem with this is that the game is about spells rather than items, so expecting a LoZ game from here will probably leave you disappointed and possibly quitting early on.  You are, indeed, spamming one or two spells early on and this will feel the norm by the time the game finds its footing and actually introduces it's core mechanic - spell crafting.  

My GAWD - once you unlock spell crafting the game goes from mindless spamming to a seemingly endless combination of custom spells.  For each core spell, you can add modifiers that will eat up a little extra mana to add an extra 'oomph' to your spell.  Tired of your enemies dodging your linear fireballs?  How bout a homing fireball?  Too generic?  How bout a fireball that upon impact, creates another fireball?  Not good enough for you?  How bout when your fireball is fired it creates more fireballs, which in turn creates more turning the immediate vicinity into a crazy amount of fireballs but draining you of all your mana.  There's options beyond that, but for the sake of non spoilers I won't mention other modifiers or core spells.

It's also worth noting the world seems both giant and small at the same time.  In total, it has 'few' areas but they're of a decent size and they do welcome you to come and go as you please.  There's a very linear storyline that I found enjoyable but simple enough, but finding unlockable modifiers for my current spells along the way in hidden areas are what made the game for me.  

In summary, the game is my favorite spell slinging game in my cancerous library once it finds its footing, but it takes its sweet time getting to that point making you think you're playing one kind of game and turning it into another later on.  I obviously found it fun enough to play and unlock nearly everything TWICE, but buyer be warned that what you see before your refund timer runs out may not be what you get in the long run, and that may actually be a good thing :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198436101221', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1535873849}
review:
A lot of fun. A kick back to SNES zelda feel of play and heart collecting while adding in the ability to cast spells. The spell system is a lot of fun being simple but, giving a feel of depth and control.

The enemies feel challanging at first, but as you learn them and, the game become easier giving you a feeling of growth

author: {'steamid': '76561197997078847', 'num_games_owned': 745, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1526722201}
review:
I logged 14+ hours playing this game on my friend's copy (thus not on this account), but I liked it so much I want to buy it on my own account to support the developers.

Apart from minor bugs which I think were eventually fixed in the patches, this game was amazing, music is top notch, perfect balance between story and rpg quests, and fights.

I was looking for rare games with magic/spell combination that are similar to the [b][u]Magicka[/u][/b] and [b][u]Lost Magic (/Takt of Magic)[/u][/b] franchises. (Comment and recommend me more if you know some!)

And this game is exactly what I was looking for. If that is you too, look no further!

Thumbs Up!

PS. The best spell combination once you have them:
[spoiler][b][u]Mega Fire Storm[/u][/b]:
Creo(igni) + Rain (+ Random (mana refund) + Size + time + mastery + at once onto a copy of the same spell to make it twice as dense)[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198010299734', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 987, 'last_played': 1603040585}
review: Loved every part of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025336134', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1165, 'last_played': 1502767578}
review:
I was a Kickstarter backer for this game, and I'm so glad. I got the game, and then after playing for a few hours, went and bought the soundtrack too. If nothing else, this game has one of the best soundtracks in video game history.

The game itself plays like a Legend of Zelda style adventure, with your mage, Zia, roaming the countryside recovering macguffins from dungeons. The twist is that you have no sword or shield. Everything, and I mean EVERYTHING, is done with magic. You have a spell book which you are constantly updating with new modifiers. So at the beginning of the game, you'll start with a fire orb. Then, you'll gain a movement modifier, and have it move forward. Then you'll add homing. Then you'll split it into 3. By the end of the game, writing your spellbook is almost like learning a new language, and it all feels organic. I think it's the first time I've actually felt like I was learning magic along with my character. It is worth playing the game for this alone.

Nonetheless, the game is not perfect. First, travel never gets easy. You still traverse on foot almost everywhere. There are teleport pads, but they don't seem to be placed in logical locations, so they are rarely used. Second, it is very, very easy to get softlocked by enemies, where they knock you down and keep hitting you for many seconds. Third, the camera angles in a few sections turn what should be easy dexterity challenges into slogs that take your whole health bar away. Finally, it is WAY too hard to regain HP. You can travel from one side of the map to the other breaking every pot on the way and still not fill up. Then, a single encounter with grunts will bring you back down to half. There's supposedly a wand that restores HP to you, but in my casual playthrough, I did not find it.

Still, this is well worth checking out!

author: {'steamid': '76561198364703535', 'num_games_owned': 599, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1522573004}

author: {'steamid': '76561198103473713', 'num_games_owned': 410, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2, 'playtime_at_review': 631, 'last_played': 1712419198}

Would love to see more!

author: {'steamid': '76561198049173414', 'num_games_owned': 680, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1521898935}
review:
TL:DR -Harry Potter + Zelda basically. 'Dungeons' and overworld puzzles like a Zelda game, but to solve them you have 4 basic spell categories you can change with runes. You can also use these spells for combat, and have a lot of freedom to adjust how you handle fights.

 For example, Igni leaves a fireball floating where you cast it that can trigger light switches, or burn things. Igni+movement=fireball spell. Igni+movement+bounce+duplicate=3 fireballs that then bounce around. Beyond that you can set up triggers, so when you cast spell A and something happens, spell B is cast. So cast a duplicate of yourself as a statue, and have it trigger cast a bouncy fireball upon cast and you've got yourself a turret. Add a turn rune to that to make it spin and shoot fireballs. Pretty fun to mess with overall. 

 Combat is ok, bosses are interesting enough. Nothing is really hard on the normal difficulty, even towards the end, but the fun of finding weird spell combos makes it ok in my opinion. 

 Puzzles aren't too hard, usually it's just applying the newest rune the game gave you. Hint systems in puzzle rooms are nicely done too. First 'hint' is just telling you if you even have the tools to do the puzzle. If you don't have the tools, come back without spending 10 minutes messing with runes to figure it out. If you do, that's all it tells you unless you really need the help, and then you can pay a tiny fee to get more hints. One neat thing was that puzzles are more difficult on the harder difficulty, rather than just combat being harder. I didn't play more than the first hour or two to see if that continued throughout the whole game, but the beginning was different for sure. 

 All in all game took 6 ish hours on a normal difficulty playthrough. Well done art style, decent dungeons, great music. Worth it IMO.

author: {'steamid': '76561198254045418', 'num_games_owned': 329, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 5129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4682, 'last_played': 1557603829}
review: Absolutely unique gameplay. You get most of the runes late in the game, but that doesn't mean you won't have quite a fun crafting spells. Still, I recommend some of steam guides to understanding when to get runes and which runes require which runes to unlock. I was bit afraid it's for the children, but that's just artstyle, and I plan to play it soon again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028265740', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1526224572}
review:
What a great game! 
At first I was put off by the chirping voices of the characters and the seemingly simple storyline but after the first 15min the game really picks up pace. It draws you in slowly as you learn the lay of the game and then boom your freedom explodes like a frost trap set to detonate lightning bolts that chain through a crowd of goblins. 

Spell customization rewards creativity and the puzzles are fun, and at times challenging, but not too frustrating. The story itself grows on you and the combat is pure joy.

I have absolutely nothing negative to say about this game at 3 hours in and based on progresion this far there is plenty more game play left. I'm going to consume this one in a sleepless binge over the weekend for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094896490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 947, 'last_played': 1518039547}
review:
Mages of Mystralia is top-down action adventure game that boldly advertises a robust customizable magic system. As the young mage Zia, you fight baddies, you explore ruins, get power-ups, and delve into mystery- you know the score. So lets get into it!

The graphics are a bright, smooth, bold, expressive, and cutesy look. This is great for a game with a camera that's pulled out to see all the action to help distinguish the components of a scene. The animations are fluid, though they can be too expressive during cut scenes. The characters flail about as if frantically conducting an imaginary orchestra. The areas themselves are wonderfully crafted and are a treat to view. The first town is especially eye catching and just seems wonderfully homey.

While the visuals are good the music is great. The orchestrated score complements the world of Mystalia swelling with intensity during combat and calming down while in the safety of town. You can tell a lot of love went into the score and its worth picking up if you enjoy video game soundtracks in general.

While the story is somewhat predicable, it's never a slog. The writing feels rushed and is a weak point. Characters are introduced and zip away constantly and their goals and distinct personalities feel shallow. Other than Zia, most characters seem to have at least one layer of smarm and smugness, which makes them unmemorable due to the ‚Äúsameyness‚Äù. The dialog balloons all start with a distinct ‚Äúhum‚Äù or ‚Äúsim speak‚Äù. Though a nice touch, it is done every time a new dialog balloon is made and can be grating 

But lets cut the heart of the matter- how does it play? Combat is the core of the game and its quite fun. The controls are responsive and the world is varied with tons of secrets tucked away. The spell crafting systems allows the player to express themselves in a lot of different ways and can result in utilitarian, powerful, goofy, or mana hungry spells. The enemy pool is shallow- you'll mostly be fighting goblins that either throw javelins or try and wack Zia with a stick. The other enemies are not much different and the same tactics can be used to smite them. Players who want one spell to tackle many problems can do so. Bosses are well done, varied, and many are a fitting capstone to a dungeon or area. Most are of a fair difficulty but always memorable. 

Is it worth the modest 20 clams though? It really depends on how you approach the magic crafting system. If you're the kind of person who wants to win and have the best spells by looking them up online, you may find the game to be average. If you're like me and love to express and toy around just to find strange, amusing, or just fun spells than Mages of Mystralia is a solid action-adventure game. The has some replay value if you're the kind of person who enjoy treasure hunting and 100% a game. It also features a ‚Äúhard mode‚Äù with a few new enemy types that use crowd control attacks. (Your mileage may vary an how you you think getting knocks down and frozen is either difficult or annoying) . If you enjoy action adventure games styled like Secret of Mana, Hyper Light Drift, Bastion, and Legend of Zelda you'll have fun with the game.

As an aside to the devs (who may never read this) the game feels open for a sequel- I hope it happens. If you choose the same magic system, I encourage you focus on more enemies vulnerable to certain spells as well as certain elements. By mixing it up with different enemy types like this you force players to use different spells rather than resort to a ‚Äúkill-all‚Äù styled fireball spell. It'll add an extra layer of depth to combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088852650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 867, 'last_played': 1517825355}
review:
the settings and lore have a simple but creative feel to its colourful background. And the Zelda style gameplay with no sword but all sorcery along with its massive combination of spells from a hurling fireball, an ice shield with a rock tower reflect, three hurling teleporting iceballs with an explosive zap bomb on contact and much more! And those spells can be used in complex puzzles to unlock more runes and power ups.

The game takes around 8-16 hours to beat if your going for a completionist or speedrun. and enemies can be a bit annoying at times when your overwhelmed. and side quests are bit obscure as soon as you get one, you have no tracker to remind you of it.

but overall I reccommend  this game for its colourful cartoonish world, creative magic system and a kickstarter gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061248171', 'num_games_owned': 966, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 1528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1472, 'last_played': 1640623935}
review:
I recived Mages of Mystralia in a "End of 2017 Borealys Games giveaway" on their official Twitter - so take this into consideration.

Ok, I need to admit that this game was pure fun and one of most enjoyable expiriences I had in last few months. The gameplay is smooth and well considered, so casting spells and vanquishing enemies is a breeze. When I first heard about other game - "Stories: the path of destinies" I imagined it will run something like that. It didn't and I end up dissapointed (even if the main character was a fox - and I loooove foxes). Mystralia doesn't have foxes, but hey - main protagonist is a redhead, so I won't hold a grudge ;).
The spellcrafting system is a great minigame that can drasticly change Your gaming expirience. I do recomend to experiment with it and I can't stress that enough. EXPERIMENT with magic! What can go wrong? It's not like You end up summoning a demon... or will You? :>
Game seems to be targeted to younger audience, but it does it in enough charming and slick way, that we- the adults will be delighted and miss the good old days, when someone else were paying bills and popquiz every now and then was our only worry.
I really hope that there will be direct sequel or at least an open world game with chqaracter creation in same universe. I would love to take it for a spin with some of my friends to bounce meta-synergic spells between us!

What I've liked
+Gameplay. Game is realy intuitive and fun to mess around.
+Spellcrafting! One of best spell-craft models I ever seen in game!
+World. World have this good'ol fable and myth flavour I particulary love.
+Story. Nothing to fancy, nothing too complicated, few twists and turns - good, relayeble and enjoyable story... well told on top of that.
+Likeable characters. Starting with our big-ears Zia, and finishing on our antagonists, most characters in this game is well put together and generally refreshing nice.
+A lot of puzzles and hidden little bonuses. It's like a remnant of a long lost era, more civilised times in gaming world, when creators rewarded explorators for their effort.

What I didn't like:
-Some puzzles. I do own several gamepads (X360, Xbone, PS4, NES and SNES replicas just to name a few and show off a bit ;) ) and I admit that playing this game on my fav X360 gamepad was most enjoyable for me, but some puzzles required fireball precision that is hard to match with analog-stick. Not big problem on PC - You can always switch for mouse and keyboard for those parts, and they generaly give You bonus runes for spells or pink orbs - so You can live without. But can be pain for complitionists.
-Harder parts in game (ghost queen for example) were not easier to do by creating more ingenius spells and utilizing better tactics, but by smashing Ybutton faster. I wanned to outsmart my boss-enemies, but usually I end up spamming them to death with my most powerfull spells.
-No spellcasting Foxes! ;)

To finish it - if You know Polish, I do have ongoingYouTube series for this game -You can always check it out!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5XOsyUSUWII&list=PLRtDTx_AqkjjL8wB6sC08JIVwvjkSXc-i

author: {'steamid': '76561197992783558', 'num_games_owned': 1889, 'num_reviews': 259, 'playtime_forever': 859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 708, 'last_played': 1516835679}
review:
Very fun, very well crafted game. The spell crafting system is brilliant, and my #1 complaint is that the game doesn't give you enough spell bits to play with until way too late. By the time I was having a blast super chaining spells, I was done with the game.

There's a little bit of unnecessary walking around (some kind of personal portal would have been nice to go with the waypoint system), and sometimes it can be tough to figure out where to go next, but that hardly detracts from the game's lovingly crafted world, enjoyable story, and fantastic spell system.

The game recommends a controller, but I played it all the way through with mouse+keyboard. WASD movement feels slightly wonky but it's not unbearable, and there was only one or two spots where I walked myself off a narrow path. Mouse aim worked really well though which made it well worth not using a controller (I'm terrible with them). Also you can rebind everything to different keys, which is very much appreciated!

Overall a wonderful little game, if it looks fun to you I'd highly recommend it.

Autant le dire tout de suite, le sc√©nario n'est qu'un pr√©texte et si les combats lors des phases d'exploration manquent un peu de dynamisme, les combats contre les boss seront bien plus int√©ressants, tout comme l'exploration des donjons pour lesquels il faudra mettre √† profit les combinaisons de runes √† notre disposition. √Ä noter qu'il y a des petites choses cach√©es un peu partout dans le jeu, qu√™tes annexes et nombreux puzzles pour r√©cup√©rer de nouvelles runes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013681158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 960, 'last_played': 1516474198}
review:
Very fun top down action/puzzle game. Interesting spellcrafting function, which basically challenges players to break the game to best of thier ability. A bit short, but that's to be expected from an indie game. I'm a big fan of the "mages as badass" genre of game rather than glass cannons which require protection. 

This game is a kinda similar to Lichdom: Battlemage, except without all the grimdark, and the develops didn't abandon it. 
 Great job overall, fingers crossed for a sequel or something in the same vein.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066838157', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 3112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3098, 'last_played': 1515974928}
review:
Mages of Mystralia is a third-person fixed-perspective action game with a unique (or at least rare) twist: You are a wizard, and have the abiliity to fill your arsenal with customized spells.

You start out being able to bash things with lightning, hurl fireballs at your enemies, create a shield, and create flat chunks of ice that let you walk across water (which is important, because Zia, your character, has Super Drowning Skills.).
Pretty soon, you'll be combining all sorts of runes into custom spells that fill the screen with enemy-assaulting mayhem.

At startup, the game says that a controller is recommended, but I had no problem with a mouse and keyboard.

Based on what Steam tells me, the game takes about 25-30 hours to beat.  Not a bad bargain! I definitely recommend it to people.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171489141', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 682, 'last_played': 1578949997}
review: The game itself showed a lot of promise and an ingenus idea. That said the story could have done better, the problems from range VS range encounters (lot seemed unavoidable from instant locking or homing) made me rage quit the game a few times, and finally more content. Giving some slack from the last one (found out this was crowd-funded) out of 10 I would give it a 7.0 - good idea, one to many shortcomings (probably cash had something to do with it)

author: {'steamid': '76561198048101201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 200, 'playtime_forever': 708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 708, 'last_played': 1515276595}
review:
I have no idea why this game hasn't gotten more mainstream attention. Cute and highly polished art style, remarkably intricate and detailed animations, cool magic and puzzle mechanics, nice overall atmosphere - on most levels this is really a gem. I was a bit hesistant to buy it, having almost never heard of it, but I'm so glad I did.

The highlight is the magic mechanic. Using a socket grid, you get to craft a wide variety of spells by adding behavior and modifier components around a central core element; the variety of spells you can craft, and of runes you can collect, is really impressive. Finding a new encounter or environment and crafting a reliable set of spells to deal with the environment is really rewarding, and experimenting with the spellcrafting system in general is really fun. There's some great puzzle design that makes imaginative use of spell properties, and the boss battles all have puzzle elements that encourage you to figure out good spells.

There's also a really fun and intuitive little rune-puzzle mechanic that's mostly used to open doors to secret areas, but then makes a surprise appearance later in the game to great effect. Everything has a puzzly feel to it, despite also being a magical action-adventure game in the moment-to-moment. It's a great combination; and despite most people seeming to beat it in 6-7 hours, I got almost 12 out of it without feeling like anything was dragging and without even finding all the secrets. There's more than enough to do in here.

Also, when you open the spellcrafting menu, the game pauses, so you can whip up new spells in the middle of a fight if you need to, which is wonderful. And the final boss encounter is divided into three sections with save checkpoints in between each, which is also great. I really appreciate these little conveniences.

The only downside is that the story is a pretty generic fantasy story with broadly unremarkable characters. This works in the sense that it allows the game to focus on introducing novel mechanics, but it would still be nice if the story were a bit more involved or surprising. The protagonist Zia started off with potential - she destroyed her home by accident using fire magic, for example - and the game suggests there are character struggles going on, such as noting that when she has to master the fire element she'll be facing her shame, but in practice that gets zero exploration in the story. There are also a handful of moments I did feel like the WASD+Mouse controls weren't quite as well-integrated as they should be, but broadly speaking it wasn't an issue.

The ending of the game unambiguously sets up a sequel, though, so hopefully the devs will get the opportunity to expand the world and story and characters in the next game. And the magic mechanics overall were just so fresh and fun, and the world was so pretty, that I didn't really care. I had a great time playing this and would heartily recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968497755', 'num_games_owned': 4818, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1589755568}
review:
La verdad que ten√≠a muchas ganas de ver el mundo que hab√≠a creado Ed Greenwood, creador de los Reinos Olvidados para D&D. Una aventura de acci√≥n con una docena de regiones a explorar, donde ciertamente me ha maravillado el dise√±o art√≠stico y el buen gusto que se ha dise√±ado cada parte del escenario.
Gr√°ficamente me ha encantado el toque a c√≥mic que le han dado a los di√°logos durante el juego, al igual que el aspecto 'cartoon', a lo Zelda Wind Waker, pero m√°s bello a mi parecer. Y la banda sonora es de 10, absolutamente maravillosa y envolvente durante el juego. Deciros que los sonidos suenan muy 'cute', son muy agradables (a excepci√≥n de la voz del narrador de la intro, ahora llegamos...).

Como aspectos negativos comentar que el combate me ha parecido muy mejorable. Noto que le falta agilidad y variedad. Se que es un juego de magos y la gracia reside en los hechizos, perdo aunque fuera una acci√≥n para rodar o hacer un peque√±o teleport estar√≠a genial y le hubiera dado un toque de profundidad al combate. Se nota tosco y no me ha acabado de convencer que no se pueda tampoco fijar a un objetivo.
Tambi√©n he tenido peque√±as rascadas en algunos tramos del juego. Es verdad que el juego se ve muy bien, pero no deber√≠a tener problemas de optimizaci√≥n.
Pero lo que para m√≠, te saca m√°s de la historia, son las escenas cinem√°ticas del juego. Son simplemente horrendas, no me gusta para nada el arte usado ni la voz del narrador. Parecen dibujos mal hechos por adolescentes, por favor... Puedo parecer exagerado, pero con los preciosista que se ve todo in-game 4 bocetos mal dibujados me sacan de quicio.

Para finalizar decir que s√≠ que recomiendo el juego,  conociendo los problemas que he nombrado. Con suerte la optimizaci√≥n la arreglar√°n con alg√∫n update, pero el resto dudo que cambien mucho.
En mi caso esperar√© a una rebaja m√°s jugosa para hacerme con la edici√≥n con la BSO que es brutal!

author: {'steamid': '76561198063931366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 837, 'last_played': 1548808903}
review: I don't write reviews often, but I just had to say something about this game. It's just so effing amazing. The spellcrafting is fun and interesting. The world is beautiful. The combat is great. And the map is a reasonable size. It's a somewhat short game clocking in at around 12 hours to max out a game file, but there is a recently added hard mode that actually changes parts of the game if you want to keep playing. I don't usualy replay games, but Mages of Mystralia proved to be so fun that I'm actually considering starting it again. I might even start a third game with the hard mode.  It's not really comparably to any other game (at least, not that I know of), but most people would probably compare it to an older top-down Legend of Zelda. I would say it's more comparable to Spiral Knights, but that's probably because I have more experience with that. Regardless, This game is definately worth picking up. It's worth picking up even more if on sale, but I'd go so far as to say it's worth it at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034302191', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 780, 'last_played': 1514583825}
review: For people who love Zelda, this game is a lot like that but it's like if Zelda and Magicka had a child together. Very fun and enjoyable all around and very unique puzzle solving.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045688017', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2456, 'last_played': 1531344243}
review:
I loved this game. The freedom to craft your own spells gave me hours of fun just considering which series of runes I could use for each battle and puzzle. 
The only gripe I have about it is that it's so short. With such a well developed gaming system, I want to see more gameplay hours, or at least a workshop for players to make their own levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961234164', 'num_games_owned': 372, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1417, 'last_played': 1514482347}
review:
This game is kind of like Magicka meets Legend of Zelda.
It's quite linear but feels fairly open, but unfortunately it's a bit short, and you don't even unlock the last major spellcraft option until right before the final dungeon.

The spellcraft system could do with more options, and more difference between options, but is overall extremely impressive; you can do some crazy stuff, and it's great.
Want to throw a rock that bounces around spawning more bouncing rocks? You can.
Want to make a cloud of lightning balls that flock around an enemy zapping them to death? You can.
Want to shoot an unholy barrage of exploding fireballs? You can.
Want to make one really big fireball that blows everything the hell up? Unfortunately you can't really make stuff directly more powerful, only make more stuff happen.

The art is gorgeous, the world lore is really interesting, and overall it's just a well made, fun game.
I'd very much like to see a sequel with much more content, more enemy variety, LONGER dungeons (they're really very short unfortunately), expanded, diversified, and balanced spellcraft system, and hell, why not multiplayer?

This game with a bunch of fun campaigns like Magicka, with cosmetic outfits, goofy stuff to do with your friends, and just MORE GAME would be amazing.
Seriously like a 9/10 experience, but definitely suffers from being just a bit short, and having options spread too close to the end of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022224976', 'num_games_owned': 823, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1529059025}
review:
I saw credits, but I didn't 100% the game.

Pros:
- It's charming 
- Not hard to play, and the spell options are pretty good
- Nice puzzles
- Minus a few frame drops, it runs quite well.

Cons:
- The last boss tower is not great
- Frame drops
- Just feels a bit meh overall.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198000735296', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1514600804}
review:
This game is great. There is literally no problem with it. I had a few frame rate drops and there was a visual glitch on the first miniboss, but otherwise the game performs flawlessly. 

Story is really good. Sometimes it seems like it skips around, but you know, for an indie game it's top notch. This game would be at home in a nintendo collection. The art is great, the music is great, the animation is pretty good, and you're going to spend at least 6 hours glued to your screen. Buy it. Please buy it and encourage this developer to make more. We need more games like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059331653', 'num_games_owned': 342, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 762, 'last_played': 1511742306}
review: An excellent adventure game if somewhat short to finish the whole thing.  Would love to see more chapters but well worth the spend, the magic system isn't quite as varied as it sounds with only a few combinations being of major use, while the rest of the uses tend to be the odd utility, but still fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032713926', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1512469751}
review: Yes, this game is cute, and the spell crafting might get interesting, but it just came off as boring to me. Given that the spell crafting is a major mechanic, I think that I should have more options when starting out. Call me impatient, but the base gameplay gets boring real quick.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005539606', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 297, 'playtime_forever': 714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1512167616}
review:
Eh, it's ok?

The spellcrafting gimmick is interesting, but you don't get many of the more interesting runes until fairly late in the game. That might be for the best, because once you master making super-broken spells and have enough mana to support them, the game ceases to be a challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005882216', 'num_games_owned': 365, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 772, 'last_played': 1512003432}
review:
Histoire: on est apparemment la seule personne qui peut sauver le monde. On pourrait innover un peu. 
Syst√®me de magie tr√®s bon: grande libert√© de cr√©ation de sorts, MAIS pas assez de mana pour les caster plus que quelques fois. 
Contr√¥les: bien, mais les perspectives sont parfois √©tranges, et l√©ger suis jet√© dans une chute √† quelques reprises en ratant un pont.
Combat: le stun lock est un choix de design, mais le recovery du stun lock eating est long. Et, comme mentionn√© plus haut, la mana n'augmente pas suffisamment avec la progression du personnage. On est le sauveur du monde, mais on peut pas caster plus que 5 sorts complexes avant d'√™tre out-of-mana. 
Le niveau de difficult√© des boss est bien; quelques boss m'ont fait mourir plus d'une fois. Comprendre la strat√©gie pour battre un boss est une chose, l'appliquer en est parfois une autre. 

Globalement, une bonne exp√©rience. Je compte terminer le jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102610208', 'num_games_owned': 489, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1653543676}
review: After reading the game's description, I expected a gameplay similar to magicka. After watching the trailer, I expected a more polished version of magicmaker. After a couple minutes of playthrough I realized it was far beyond these comparisons. Mages of Mystralia offers more room for creativity and a more engaging storyline and gameplay than I could have expected. It manages to expand upon hours of entertainment using simplicity. Controls are extremely easy to grasp and character progression grows on a steady and pleasant pace. Furthermore, the soundtrack is amazing and the scenery, albeit simple, doesnt't cease to amaze with a mixture of small details and a bit of lore. The downside of the game is its length. The game is in no way too short, but replayability is not very encouraged, and by the end of the game, players might miss the pleasant pace of progression this game offered. In other words, although it offers just as much, or more, play time as any other game, it's such a pleasant game that it makes us wish to keep this pace for a little longer, something that few other games can offer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066292318', 'num_games_owned': 464, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1559956811}
review:
[h1]Most spellbinding and creative game[/h1]

Mages of Mystralia is a cutesy indie game where you play as a Mage who has seeked refuge in a town of other mages in a world where magic is outlawed. You must utilise spells and your magic to get through combat and puzzles. This game makes you be creative with different combinations of runes to make custom spells and unique attacks, lots of puzzles to utilise cool spell effects as well as defeat enemies in an interesting way.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
- Great cartoony graphics
- Fun magic
- Creative spellmaking
- Interesting story
- Lots of cool environments
- Loads of puzzles
- Spellbinding soundtrack

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- There are a few bugs to be had.
- Because this game also utilises puzzles and forcing your creativity to make spells to complete them. You can be stuck depending on how good with puzzles you are.

[h1]My Rating: 9/10[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198078367600', 'num_games_owned': 153, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 836, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 806, 'last_played': 1509930186}
review:
I was about 8hrs into my game when I decided to save, close up, and get some dinner.

Came back to a glitch. Save file was replaced with one at 0% completion, but it had some obvious signs of the mechanics from the original file remaining (i.e. there were flowers in the flowerbed in Haven).

Tried uninstalling and reinstalling. Did not work. Ended up having to go into the save files and restore an backed-up file from earlier (at least they back up previous versions of saves so I could do so).

I'm really enjoying the game and was a backer of the Kickstarter campaign, but I can't recommend something that will delete your data when you log out without warning. Maybe hold off a bit longer until more of the bugs are squashed, or be prepared to go in and fix up glitches on your own

author: {'steamid': '76561198027717869', 'num_games_owned': 384, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 1067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1044, 'last_played': 1660335508}
review:
Starts off a little too slow for my taste but if you stick with it, it becomes interesting once you start getting some runes you can use.

Unfortunately you can quickly create spells that literally clear an entire screen full of enemies and actually one-shot even the final boss without even draining half your mana. So it could use some rebalancing in that regard, but it's still an enjoyable time-sink if you don't think about it too hard.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031601206', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 846, 'last_played': 1509636341}
review:
This game has some truly awesome potential that's wasted by bugs and badly made gameplay elements that ruin it quickly. Examples include :

- The At Once rune is broken : one particular challenge that requires the At Once rune and above all requires some careful positioning to aim fireballs that go in an arc and backwards is rendered impossible due to the At Once rune completely messing with the starting direction of the spells. Something as simple as casting several spells in a row with the same starting conditions was failed. Simply unbelievable.

- Having to mash a button to break free from freezing effects : mechanics that require button mashing have already become a no-no a long time ago. Having to mash a button normally unused in combat to break free from an effet that freezes you on place and, worse, can be re-applied immediatly after breaking free ? That's pure unfairness. Simply having the freeze effect last a set duration would be enough, and letting the player react to the next potentially freezing attack before getting frozen again would make the game actually fair, rather than having some useless breaking-free animation that prevents the player from even raising a shield.

- Those goblin lightning spearmen are insane : as if splash damage on ranged attacks didn't make the game hard enough, get ready for a ranged attack that splits into 4 bolts that go in 4 separate perpendicular directions, are insanely fast, have no range limit, penetrate shields and above all have a totally random pattern. What makes a game of this kind fair is enemies having a degree of predictability. Being hit by an attack must be mainly the player's fault for not paying attention, not an occurence of pure randomness.

- A bug that simply makes a boss disappear and denies you of any rewards for beating it : at least it didn't prevent the story to continue, but still, having the boss simply disappear befire then end of the fight and neither getting the achievement and the upgrade to health and mana is infuriating. When the game auto-saves and the only way to get them is to start all over again, that's when you want to throw your controller through your monitor.

Badly programmed mechanics, unfair fights and bugs that potentially break the game, I cannot recommend it unless it gets patched to fix this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969364344', 'num_games_owned': 1670, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 1050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1027, 'last_played': 1518499540}
review:
TL;DR: Zelda with a splash of Magicka.

Slightly longer: if you like Zelda games, you'll almost certainly like this. You have no melee weapons; even your melee is a spell. And like in Magicka, you get to "assemble" your spells from pieces. This gives you a fair amount of flexibility to play the way you want, although most of these things are unlocked gradually.

The graphics are gorgeous, the story is actually decent if unoriginal (the in-game lore is actually great, though!)

Polish-wise, I could almost believe this was from a AAA studio. I didn't encounter a single memorable bug my whole playthrough. (Worst thing that happened is I got stuck once)

Highly recommend, even at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198151014665', 'num_games_owned': 176, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1779, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1651, 'last_played': 1508620389}
review:
Pros:
Nice world
Nice game design
Interesting spell design
Enjoyable puzzels and dungeons

Cons:
A few minor bugs
Enemies are not very diverse 

I played through this game twice (one playthrough for each mode) and had a lot of fun beating it. Even tough there are still some bugs in this game even after the updates. For example, sometimes a spell just keeps being in your list eventhough you deleted it and it will keep popping up no matter what. Also i completed the game both times a 100%, but through bugs i didn¬¥t get the achievement, or sometimes i collect a purple orb but the game doesn¬¥t register it. Also some of the puzzels are a little buggie and i beat one or two by acciedent because an orb glitched through a wall or something like that.
All in all it¬¥s a fun game for every age. You can just relax and play it, solve some puzzels and enjoy a nice little tale. The game design is also quite nice, your characater becomes stronger through the game by getting new modifikations for your spells, more Mana and more Life. 
If you are looking for a neat little game for the side this game is for you.
